Two hundred jobs. God, when I say it out loud like that it still doesn't feel real. [happy] I keep driving through downtown and seeing all these cars in the parking lots again, you know? [warmly] Like actual people going to work, not just empty buildings anymore. My mom called me yesterday crying because, um... because her neighbor's son just got hired at the new facility. [emotional] Kid was about to move away, just like I almost did. [pause] 

I remember when everyone thought I was, uh, completely delusional. [chuckle] "Economic development officer" they said, like it was some made-up title I gave myself. And honestly? There were nights I'd sit in that tiny office thinking maybe, hmm, maybe they were right. [quietly] Maybe I was just wasting everyone's time. 

[relieved] But then the first company said yes. And then another one started asking questions. And suddenly we had—I mean, it happened so fast at the end. [excited] All these pieces just clicked together and boom, here we are! [trailing off] Two hundred families that don't have to leave now...

[very sincerely] You know what gets me the most? It's seeing kids at the grocery store again. Like, the school actually had to hire another teacher. [emotional] We haven't hired a new teacher in fifteen years. [sigh] This town was dying, and now it's... it's breathing again.
